poem:
**White Smoke, Black Earth**

White smoke lifts above Rome;  
below, Los Angeles smoulders.  
A mayor raises his hand—  
small as a prayer.  
In Washington the desks are emptied;  
names fall like screws from a pocket.  

An old electrician, not of that church,  
listens for forgiveness  
while wars continue to eat.  
Even the drunk raccoon staggers—  
our comic saint—through ash.
